messages: d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:55): I have this really annoying problem. pressing tab in insert mode is mapped to some sort of auto completion when i have non-space charachters to the left of the cursor. The thing is I get an error when the completion-thingy dont find any matching words.
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:56): that is kinda not so good if i want to do stuff like ; $foo<Tab>= 'bar'
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:56): I have not found where this auto completion thingy is done. But im using ubuntu dapper and have installed vim via apt.
d159fc61c35985a7d619284a2ffb639b (22:57): qzio, erm, that's not a default setup afaik, you've probably got a script in your $VIMRUNTIME that is setting up some autocomplete stuff
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:57): that sucks :(
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (22:57): qzio: that's probably the SuperTab plugin
d159fc61c35985a7d619284a2ffb639b (22:57): qzio, yeh, you should be able to just disable the plugin
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (22:57): better to just remove it. it just gets in the way
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:58): Yes it does. If i want auto completion i want to set it up  myself.
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:58): this stupid thing just ruins my temper :)
d159fc61c35985a7d619284a2ffb639b (22:58): qzio, yeh check out :help ins-completion
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (22:58): so turn it off.
d159fc61c35985a7d619284a2ffb639b (22:59): qzio, that's probably what you actually want
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:59): argument: thanks!
d159fc61c35985a7d619284a2ffb639b (22:59): qzio, are you sure you didn't install any like apt-get install vim-extras or anything?
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (22:59): it doesn't, unless they're explicitly modifying Debian's packages
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:59): argument: I could be responsible for this yes...
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (22:59): But I dont want to admit it!
d159fc61c35985a7d619284a2ffb639b (22:59): qzio, i'm pretty sure they've got a vim-plugins package that comes with ubuntu
d159fc61c35985a7d619284a2ffb639b (23:00): qzio, i've got ubuntu on my other drive, i just haven't booted into it for a while :)
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (23:00): weii! i got my ta bback
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:00): yeah, vim-scripts has the SuperTab plugin, but it's not in the 'runtimepath'
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:00): so, you'd have to symlink/copy it somewhere to enable it
d89b0f1fff1cfe1072c98fe39f2a7263 (23:01): I think i've downloaded this supertab from somewhere. I have a vaug memorie of doing stuff in ~/.vim/plugins
286e56b2c6060f77584a7ab54532284f (23:02): qzio, are you using Rails plugin for vim?
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:11): is there someway to stop vim from trying to use X11 support (other than -X or recompiling)?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:12): :help 'clipboard
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:12): the exclude option is probably what you want
9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (23:12): is there a way to rename the current buffer you're editing?
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:13): the issue is that there's no X server running on the system. So it takes vim several seconds to try to connect to those resources (and fails)
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:13): and you may want :help :saveas
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:13): tpope: that won't prevent Vim from trying to connect to an X server when started if it has X support and sees a $DISPLAY
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:13): Zathrus: if there's no X server, why is $DISPLAY set?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:13): jamessan, if you are right it conflicts with the documentation

fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:14): jamessan: ok; a slight correction -- there's no X server on my local system (because I don't run one unless I need to). I guess if I unset DISPLAY then it'd work sanely.
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:14): Zathrus: yes
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:15): tpope: the attempt to connect to the X server happens before any vimrc files are read, iirc. it has nothing to do with 'clipboard'
9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (23:15): none of those actually rename the file though, they all change the current name - if you change a.txt to b.txt you end up with two files: a.txt and b.txt
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:16): jamessan: echo "set clipboard=exclude:.*" >> ~/.vimrc; DISPLAY=:1 vim
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:16): tpope: ah, actually the docs say it can be the same as using -X
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:17): thanks tpope and jamessan
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:17): mapop: you didn't ask how to rename the file, you asked how to rename the buffer
9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (23:17): jamessan: oh, sorry about that. Is there a way to rename the file?
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:18): yeah, use your shell
9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (23:18): lol, nice.
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:18): there's the rename() script call in vim as well
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:19): but it's unclear if it affects open buffers
9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (23:20): I did look around vim.org and nobodys written a tip or script for a home grown in-vim rename. Kinda shocking.
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:20): buffers are separate from files. it'll probably move the file out from under you, and a :w would write out to the original name
9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (23:20): hmm, rename kinda works, not exactly - it does rename the file on the filesystem, but the buffername stays the same. pretty close.
abe59155aa41ae19e4ea964e9dd4b200 (23:37): http://www.bagdadsoftware.de")

361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (23:42): I'm having character sequences like this... <82> ... come up, and I want to run a replace to get rid of them, but aren't sure how to replicate them in the command. Thoughts?
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (23:43): I know, for example, that <82> is equivalent to ?© but I'm not sure what the relation is.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:52): Elazar: try pressing ga on top of the character
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:52): :he digraphs   is probably a good start

9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (23:52): Seems like this is kinda what I was looking for wrt to 'rename':com! -nargs=1 -complete=file Rename f <args>|silent call rename("^R%","<args>")|silent file <args>|w

59011d6a7b65cb2c8972af4beca52305 (23:53): I've looked around to see if vim has this feature or not, and I don't believe so, but I want to make sure.. so, can I specify somehow a timeout, where if the user is not actively editing a file in vim for more than x seconds or x minutes, it closes the file (and/or exits vim)?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:53): that doesn't look like ?© to me
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (23:54): Well, it's *supposed* to be outputted as that, and <82> is just what I happen to get instead.
49e5f50d2f7db1abf3c69c779b794d28 (23:55): howdy
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (23:55): it should be  00e9
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (23:55): i asked this before but never found answer in :help.. how do i make it so 'h' will go to the previous line, when at column 0
49e5f50d2f7db1abf3c69c779b794d28 (23:56): I just now installed vim7 and I'm wondering how to 'tap' into the ruby syntax completion
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:56): and I gave you an answer
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:56): which I forgot
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:56): stu: :he whichwrap
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:56): I remember it was highly discouraged
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (23:57): but whichwrap will happily let you do so
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (23:57): mapop: you can use expand('%') instead of ^R
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (23:57): vim will happily let you do that too!
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (23:58): maru: Should be, yeah. Not sure why it's doing this.
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (23:58): Elazar: where are you trying it? terminal?
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (23:59): maru: The replace, you mean? Inside of vim.
9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (23:59): jamessan, thanks.
49e5f50d2f7db1abf3c69c779b794d28 (23:59): tpope: you're coding in ruby (ror) how can I do completion?
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (00:00): Elazar: naw I mean what vim are you using?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:00): the_mug, File.ex<C-X><C-O>
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:00): the_mug: or, with rails.vim, has_<C-X><C-U>
49e5f50d2f7db1abf3c69c779b794d28 (00:01): tpope: I have no idea what that means. :-/
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:02): the_mug: :help key-notation
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (00:02): Elazar: terminal, gvim or winvim? :)
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:02): maru: Terminal I think. :P
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (00:03): Elazar: and if you type ?© you do not get it?
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (00:03): Zathrus: thanks
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:03): maru: Nope, it doesn't seem to relate ?© with <82> when I try to run a replace using ?©.
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (00:04): tpope: you told me to :he <some topic> which i couldn't find an answer in
61894b21be75260c4964065b1eecec4d (00:04): is tha channel archived somewhere?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:04): stu: probably :help 'whichwrap', the same that Zathrus said
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:06): 2006-07-30_14:32:57 <tpope> stu I didn't know but I found it from :help h
49e5f50d2f7db1abf3c69c779b794d28 (00:06): tpope: so you created rails.vim? cool. how do you install the rails.vba vim ball?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:06): but I gave you an answer
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:06): the_mug: edit it, and :so %
49e5f50d2f7db1abf3c69c779b794d28 (00:07): tpope: I feel I'm behind on my Vi... where can I catch up?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:07): and if you are really behind, :help version6
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (00:09): tpope: yeah i just grepped it too, heh
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (00:09): tpope: i just went back to :he h and /whichwrap/'d and i found it there at the bottom
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:09): maru: No idea? :P
0b2d182efae23710a3f4f438e1744306 (00:09): i read a bunch before though and didn't find it
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (00:10): Elazar: Care to explain the problem in more detail, my brain is slow today :)
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:10): maru: NP. OK, I'm running vim 6.3. More specifically, I'm secure shelled into a CentOS 4.2 box and using the command line version.
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:11): maru: There are sequences like this... <82> ... that vim is treating as a single character.
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:11): maru: I want to get rid of them via a replace, but I'm not sure how to input them into vim so it recognizes them properly.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:11): as you were already told, they are not e's

361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:11): tpope: I don't know what they are, but I know what they're supposed to be. Regardless, all I need is to know how to input sequences like <82> into vim so that it replaces them in the document accordingly.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:12): there's two answers
007a84eb39595be220c41bda71bca738 (00:12): Elazar: ctrl-v x82
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:13): maru: That's what I was looking for. Thank you!
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (00:13): that wasn't me :)
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:13): tpope: And thank you as well. :)
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:14): maru, tpope: Don't suppose either of you know if the same sequence will work in sed? :P
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:15): you will probably have to do it in octal
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:15): and I don't know if that will work either
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (00:15): maybe in gnu sed
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:15): tpope: Is the 202 octal that vim outputted earlier correct?
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:15): tpope: For ?© I mean.
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:15): tpope: OK, thank you again. :)
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (00:17): hmm my ?© is 351 octal
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (00:17): Elazar: what encoding are you using?
361699642668dafef3cdea989c6c5007 (00:17): UTF-8 as far as I know.
007a84eb39595be220c41bda71bca738 (00:18): 0202 is a control character in latin-1/unicode
007a84eb39595be220c41bda71bca738 (00:18): unicode ?© is 0xE9
609252e8595f84db3ab53f287c7d4dea (00:19): ah the joys of encodings
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (00:19): base 256, yo
172acf7d320d310787a351a36dbae3f8 (00:23): how do I set auto syntax highlighting in ~/.vimrc?
007a84eb39595be220c41bda71bca738 (00:23): syntax enable
172acf7d320d310787a351a36dbae3f8 (00:24): set befor that or just syntax enable?
172acf7d320d310787a351a36dbae3f8 (00:25): there, yay
172acf7d320d310787a351a36dbae3f8 (00:26): mauke, thanks :D
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (00:26): use syntax on, not syntax enable
04ee6cce4c0d7a48ba8443557a8a68eb (00:29): There's no difference in syntax on or syntax enable
007a84eb39595be220c41bda71bca738 (00:29): yes, there is
04ee6cce4c0d7a48ba8443557a8a68eb (00:29): The ":syntax" commands are implemented by sourcing a file.  To see exactly how
04ee6cce4c0d7a48ba8443557a8a68eb (00:29): this works, look in the file:
04ee6cce4c0d7a48ba8443557a8a68eb (00:29): :syntax enable      $VIMRUNTIME/syntax/syntax.vim
